content.description: Easy moves lead up to a small ledge. The remainder of the route is very engaging all the way to the anchors. A seam bearing some nice pockets leads to a small roof. The crux involves clearing this roof, but save some energy for the steep section above.
content.location: This fine climb begins hallway between the right two bolts on the via ferrata.

content.description: Climbs easier (9 ish) ground with some fun traversing to a challenging roof pull. Lower section has some lichen that demands careful foot placements. Bolt line is dead straight but the route wanders in the middle (in a fun way.)
content.protection: 10 bolts (dark brown) to carabiners at anchors.
content.location: Look for dark brown bolt line that is across the trail from large boulders. Climb is 2nd bolt line to the left of a large (several feet tall) vertical pocket that's about half-way up the wall. Currently (as of Jan 2014) the 11th climb from the right of the wall. The one to the right is 10d also, and to the left is a 10a.

content.description: Laugh your way up to the steep technical crux, which is sustained and tricky, finally reaching a small hole. Moderate moves reach the anchors.
content.location: The first route right of the big holes.

content.description: Interesting climbing gains the rest ledge. Sustained moves reach the anchors.
content.location: Start on a small buttress between two short vertical cracks.

content.description: This climb moves up some easy rock to some very difficult moves, culminating in the crux near the top. Look for the anchors out right.
content.location: Located about 12 feet right of 'Nobody Puts Baby in a Corner'

climbs.name: The Pone Tony AKA Larry's Route

content.description: A long and fun route over cool features through the middle of the wall.
content.location: The climb that passes through the mini cave/large pod

climbs.name: Nobody Puts Baby in a Corner

content.description: One of the best routes on the wall; an area classic! Climb up face, past a tiny roof, to a left angling set of moves that reaches the bottom of the major right-facing corner system. Continuously challenging climbing ascends this corner, but often the moves are just out to the right. At the top, move back left, and up to the anchors.
content.location: route to the right of 'Coulda Been a Contender'

climbs.name: May the Force be With You

content.description: One of the finest routes on the wall, with multiple hard sections, and a variety of climbing styles. Once the crux section is attained, the moves are sustained on superior rock. The final slab passing the pockets will require Jedi mind tricks!
Start on either route to the left or right for two bolts, then engage this line, boldly going up to the overhang near the top. Once above this, an anchor is located in a small alcove.
content.location: between 'May the Force be With You' and 'There's No Crying in Baseball'

content.description: This entertaining route climbs through a lower angle section of grey rock (4 or 5 bolts) to a small roof that is fun and not the hardest part of the climb. Crux is near the top of the grey rock section, about halfway up the climb. Plenty of excellent footholds get you through the touch sections, including the roof.  Great climb for the grade!
content.location: Currently (as of Jan 2014) the second route from the right on this wall.

content.description: Climbs over two bulges/roofs then stays left of week dihedral. Good movement with some cryptic holds, fun foot sequences, and it is surprisingly not that pumpy. Really fun climbing and would get three stars, but the bottom third is on heavily fractured rock (aka "Choss").  Belayer should stand to the right and wear a helmet.
content.protection: Well bolted to carabiners at anchors.  A couple of shoulder length slings will help ease rope drag at the bulges, but they aren't entirely necessary.
content.location: Follow the trail past a fixed hand-line rope. This is the first set of bolts that is about 10 feet past the fixed hand-line. Currently (as of Jan 2014) the 14th bolt line from the right of this wall. The climb to the right is a 10b.

content.description: Look for a short, right-angling crack at the base,  and bolts that head straight up above its left side.Easy climbing leads to a steep section, where the crux in encountered. Challenging but easier moves pass the left side of a huge hole, and up to the anchors.
content.location: This is currently the farthest left route on the wall, and it is located approximately 50 feet left of 'Coulda Been a Contender'

content.description: This climb is great for the grade and pulls a fun bulge/roof on huge jugs with great feet.  The roof isn't even the crux, it's a rewarding treat at the end of the climb. It is longer than the 5.8 that is two climbs over, and gives a better warm-up. Brown bolts/hangers.
content.location: Look for the brown bolts/hangers. Starts about 15-20 feet after the trail gets to the wall and is the first climb where the belay is basically ON the trail. Currently (as of Jan 2014) the third route from the right.

content.description: Head up to steepening rock, and fun moves to reach a small ledge. Interesting climbing on great stone reaches the anchors.
content.location: The start is directly above the rightmost bolt on the via ferrata, off a small ledge.

content.description: Start up easy stone to a very technical and difficult set of thin moves, which relent before the rest ledge. A small but strenuous roof is encountered, then beautiful rock to the anchors.
content.location: This is the route immediately left of the big holes in the middle of the wall (the Pone Tony).

content.description: Starts with moderate climbing that gets more challenging as you ascend, making for a nice warm-up climb.  Climbs up face to steeper ground with a nice section of crack.
content.protection: Well bolted with carabiners at anchors.
content.location: Starts where the trail dips slightly and is flush with the wall. Currently (Jan 2014) this is the 4th climb from the right on this wall.

climbs.name: Frankly, I Don't Give a Damn

content.description: Climbs up a corner system using plenty of stemming and a little lieback.  Gets steeper right before the chains.  It's 5.8, but you have to actually pay attention to get through it.  Movement is not entirely intuitive and the stemming is on rock that doesn't feel as sticky as you'd hope. I only give this one star, but if you love stemming and are in the mood for something different from most of Homestead, this may be for you! Bolts to carabiners at anchors.
content.location: Currently (as of Jan 28, 2014) the farthest right route at this wall.  It is (currently) the first route that you encounter as you come up the trail. Anchors have carabiners to lower.

content.description: Although there is a bit of blocky, fractured stone, this is still a worthy climb. Head up and out left onto the steep headwall, and up to the anchors.
content.location: This route begins below the right side of an obvious overhang, just left of the major right-facing corner system.

content.description:
NOTE: Be aware that many of these climbs are directly above climbs at Bonetown. Pay attention to what's below you, don't trundle rocks and use extreme caution if there are climbers below you, or even better, move over to a climb that is not above them!

 This area was developed largely by Scott Ayers, Dan Cohen, and Tanya Bok, but the first route was bolted by Larry Meier (who passed away in Dec 2015). It features a nice group of long (60 to 80 feet) 5.10 to 5.11 climbs with a few 8s/9s to warm-up on. It's a good area for the start of the day because many of the routes on the right start on easier ground and get progressively harder, giving you a long warm-up before you get to the crux. This west facing cliff is shady in the morning and gets sun after about 2:00 or 3:00 in the afternoon. The rock is OK quality with many routes (even an 8!) that pull a small roof. And the roof often isn't the crux! This area is nice if you're new to the Homestead because the climbing is a little less intense but still requires technique.
